Johnny Marr and vocalist and front man
Morrissey The Smiths were formed in 1982
and disbanded just five years later
mostly due to personal and creative

which is obviously tragic considering

together like imagine if the Cure cut

and Commercial Success which I think is

the continued fandom for The Smiths I

now personally I will take a moment in
this review to say I'm not the biggest
fan of their work I think I tend to be a
little picky with some of their stuff
like of course I personally Vibe with
the messaging of songs like meeta's
murder and it's pretty easy for me to
get caught up in the wild danceable
post-punkisms of tracks like barbarism
begins at home but by that same token
I'm completely unimpressed by tracks
such as rush home Ruffians Morrissey
brings Posh and poetic catterwalling on
this track with no real melodic
destination in sight and he does this
over weirdly chipper drums and acoustic
guitars whose grooves wear out their
one-dimensional welcome pretty fast if I
wanted something this sweet upbeat
English and slightly Punky I'd rather
listen to the clashes hateful which I
know sounds dismissive but I do think
Morrissey and the Smiths are an example
of a band that sometimes are a little
too convinced of their own genius but
they're also an example of a band that
when they're on they are really on as in
their short time together as a band I
think they unlock the fullest potentials
for poeticism or reverence Whimsy and
Bittersweet romance in pop music which
is why the Smiths and The Queen Is Dead
in my opinion are so special that and
they helped set the aesthetic tone at
least somewhat for pop an alternative
rock through the 90s I mean this
record's already received its fair share
of accolades enemy named it the greatest
album of all time it is gold in the U.S
platinum in the UK so I hope you don't
mind if I Heap some extra praise onto
this thing too as The Queen Is Dead is
an album that is thrilling Charming
captivating and smart from front to back
whether it's the fiery six minute opener
and title track which is driven by these
throttling snares and bass shrill and
watery Rhythm guitars too that hit a
great pace and give morrissey's brutal
and contemptuous shots at the monarchy
an explosive punch the words alone are
on this deep level of seething nastiness
even if Morrissey is more flowery and
poetic about his language than let's say
Johnny Rotten was on God Save the Queen
the following cut frankly Mr shankly is
one of my favorite tracks X here the
song is a tongue-in-cheek meditation on
success while also referencing some
disagreements that Morrissey had with
the head of rough trade records at the
time calling him out as a flatulent pain
in the ass as Morsi also details his
aspirations to be famous saying he
prefers it to being righteous and holy
which is funny because if there's one
thing to know about Morrissey it's that
he will kneecap his own success just to
say what is on his mind pretty much
faster than anyone his own
self-awareness of this is essentially
what inspired the lead single to the
album Big Mouth strikes again but as far
as shankly goes I've always loved these
subtle ska nods and the instrumentation
on this track from the bass and upstroke
guitar then you have those springy
almost alien Melodies that soar in on
the chorus that sound fantastic sweet
addictive I know it's over as another
highlight for me on the record that
showcases the band's knack for aesthetic
Beauty and Dynamics the instrumentation
on this cut is so colorful and sweet and
subtle it is a valid fit for a slow
dance with sparkling guitars underscored
by a Rhythm Section you can really get
lost in plus this is one of the many
moments on this LP where morrissey's
writing and vocals truly shine really
Bittersweet in its portrayal of
loneliness equating the end of a love
with death itself which is supremely
dark yes but Marcy also works these
poignant rays of light into the lyrics
too it kind of makes you wonder where
this guy went the themes of loneliness
and isolation continue on to the even
more agonized and tortured never had no
one ever which narratively adds in this
sort of creepy I'm outside your house
now angle which really sends a chill

is pure Bittersweet jungle pop Bliss the
Pepe drums and guitars are infectious as

writers in hand sad sentiments about all

Authority there is a light that never

maybe my favorite Smith song of all time
I love the jangly and trancing guitars
The Groovy bass and drums the sharp

touches of synthesizer throughout the
track but it's really morrissey's lyrics
and vocals that sell the song for me
first off there's the sad transience of
not having a home or a place to be in
his lyrics then there's also the
sentiment of wanting your last moments
in life to be spent with someone you

some girls are bigger than others is a

Rock instrumental does make for another
entrancing moment in the track list
Final thoughts on this record it is

pop album production writing
